nodes.bodyText: This uncovers an existing issue (#2176), which causes CI to fail. If we drop this part, OR fix #2176, OR comment out the flaky assertion, the CI should pass.
This PR is based on PR #2182
But document may not contain field with this key name
Thanks for the review. I am not sure If I got you, can you elaborate a bit / give an example? Are you talking about the case when a mixed index is built, but reindexing not yet done?

Suppose next vertex schema
id
name
phone

and query has('phone')
Some vertices has phone field, some none. But lucene index build query with MatchAllDocsQuery and ignore specific filed phone. All vertices will be retrieved
thanks! I shouldn't have overlooked this scenario. I will look into it.
This should be checked in isHasFilterStep, too
Why is the currentStep's successor set here, if that step is removed anyway?
You could use TraversalHelper.replaceStep(currentStep, hasStep, traversal)

Nit: A nicer solution would be to split this test up into two separate methods and have one of them test Geoshape and one everything else but Geoshape. You can then @disable the Geoshape test in the Lucene and Solr implementations of JanusGraphIndexTest.
This way, the abstract test class stays free of backend related stuff. For examples, have a look at JanusGraphTest and it's implementing classes for different storage backends.

I find it easier to understand what these different properties are used for, if each one is named by the data type it uses. In addition, the selection of properties can be trimmed down to only contain a single property per data type.

I'm not sure .has("prop", P.neq(null)) and .has("prop") are equal. At least, in TinkerPop 3.5.0 null values are supported.
That said, I didn't check this PR much. Maybe I just miss something

Great explanation @li-boxuan !
Agree, we don't need to support null values as for now because it is an optional feature in TinkerPop
